{{Love table}}
 
{{Love table}}
−
'''Love''' is any of a number of [[emotion]]s and [[experience]]s related to a sense of strong [[affection]] or profound [[oneness (concept)|oneness]].<ref name="oxford"/> It is most often conceived of [[romantic love|romantically]], as a deep, [[ineffability|ineffable]] [[feeling]] of intense and tender [[interpersonal attraction|attraction]] to another.<ref name="dic">http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/love</ref> It is shared in passionate or [[intimacy|intimate]] [[interpersonal relationship]]s, and is characterized by a mix of [[emotion]]al and [[human sexuality|sexual]] desire. However, in different contexts, ''love'' can refer to numerous other feelings, including [[platonic love]], [[love (religious views)|religious love]], [[familial love]], and, more casually, to anything or anyone that one considers strongly pleasurable, enjoyable, desirable, or preferred, including activities and foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word ''love'' also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: "I just love how politicians always make empty promises."</ref><ref name="dic"/> This diverse range of meanings in the singular word ''love'' is often contrasted with the plurality of [[Greek words for love|Greek words for ''love'']], reflecting the concept's depth, versatility, and complexity.
+
'''Love''' is any of a number of [[emotion]]s and [[experience]]s related to a sense of strong [[affection]] or profound [[oneness (concept)|oneness]].<ref name="oxford"/> Depending on the context, ''love'' can embody a wide variety of intended meanings. It is commonly conceived of [[romantic love|romantically]], as a deep, [[ineffability|ineffable]] [[feeling]] of intense and tender [[interpersonal attraction|attraction]]<ref name="dic">http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/love</ref>. It is shared in passionate or [[intimacy|intimate]] [[interpersonal relationship|interpersonal]] and [[human sexuality|sexual]] relationships. The romantic dimension of love may also be extended or refined<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book

Mascaró translator)</ref> [[familial love]], and, more casually, anything considered strongly pleasurable, desirable, or preferred; including activities and foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word ''love'' also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: "I just love how politicians always make empty promises."</ref><ref name="dic"/> This diverse range of meanings in the singular word ''love'' is often contrasted with the plurality of [[Greek words for love|Greek words for ''love'']], reflecting the concept's depth, versatility, and complexity.
